awd_titl_txt: The role of protein specificity in the evolution of regulatory RNAs
awd_abstract_narration:
Ribonucleic acids (RNA) play many roles in the cell, and one of such roles that became clear only in the recent years is to control production of metabolites and to respond to stresses. RNA regulators are often very different in different organisms; it is thought that they are more diverse, or at least harder to recognize, than protein regulators. This research will study how similar ribosomal proteins in different bacterial species have evolved to recognize different RNA regulators. This project will provide numerous training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, and the project team will continue their work in introducing school girls in the at-risk communities in Boston area to science.

The objective of this project is to examine the relationship between protein specificity and the diversity of RNA gene regulators observed in nature. The model systems used in this project are the bacterial RNA regulators of ribosomal protein synthesis and their protein interaction partners. Some of these regulators are conserved in most bacteria; in other cases there is extraordinary diversity across different bacterial phyla. We hypothesize that proteins interacting with several diverse natural regulators are likely to have larger pools of RNA partners compared to proteins that interact with conserved regulators. To investigate this we will first use in vitro approaches to compare the RNA interaction pools of ribosomal proteins from different organisms. The protein-interacting RNAs that are derived from this approach will then be assessed to determine what additional features are necessary to allow regulation in response to protein over-expression within cells. By comparing the results from proteins that have many natural RNA-binding partners with those from proteins that have a single conserved RNA partner, we will determine the role that protein specificity plays in driving diversity of regulatory RNAs observed in nature.

por.por_cntn:
There are three major project outcomes from this award. Two that directly address intellectual merit, and one that addresses broader impacts. The first major outcome of this work is establishment that homologous RNA proteins in distinct species may have very different RNA-binding spheres. In the case studied, ribosomal protein S15 homologs from diverse bacterial species interact with RNA-pools showing only some, but not complete overlap. This suggests that one of the causes behind the diversity of RNA regulators we observe in natural systems is differences in the homologous interacting proteins.

 

The second project outcome is the development of a fluorescence activated droplet sorting assay that allows the biological activity of RNA gene regulators to be assessed in high-throughout. The development of this assay involved extensive optimization of the reporter proteins, promoter sequences, and strains utilized in addition to optimization of the formation of microfluidic droplets. Yet, the formation of microfluidic droplets containing individual microcolonies proved to still not be sufficient high-throughput to enable frequency-based analysis of gene expression via high-throughput sequencing (the numbers of droplets achieved were not large enough to overcome the noise inherent in the expression and sorting of the droplets). However, the extensive optimization of the reporter assay allowed us to circumvent the need for microcolonies to amplify the reporter signal. If individual cells are sorted, we can easily accommodate sufficient numbers to get appropriate signal for frequency-based high-throughput sequencing quantification.  Thus, all though the assay development itself proved to be an obstacle, we ultimately still achieved the overarching goal of assaying gene expression for individual clonal E. coli at high-throughput and have plans to use this assay in the future.

 

Finally, the broader impacts of this award on science education and society include the participation of approximately 200 5-7th grade women in science workshops through the WST program at Boston College over the life of the award. This program recruits undergraduate women to serve as mentors and organizers for a four-day set of science workshops that take place over four consecutive Saturdays in January/February annually. Despite the COVID-19 epidemic, workshops were successfully conducted in 2018, 2019, 2020, and 2022.  Finally, this award also contributed to the development of the scientific workforce by funding the Ph.D. work of 3 graduate students (including one who identifies as a person of color), two of whom have already completed their dissertations, as well as the undergraduate research experiences for at least 5 undergraduates.
